intro: Ochrocarpos chapelieri, commonly known as the Cape York quandong, is a flowering plant native to northern Australia. It belongs to the family Myrtaceae and is characterized by its smooth, greyish bark and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in spring, followed by edible, yellow-orange fruits. It thrives in sandy soils and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
